description.text:
This hack and the code attached allows a user to control a fifth stepper with a Gen 3 motherboard.  If you have a second stepper driven extruder, this will allow you to do dual extrusion.  
The unused SCL and SDA pins are used for the fifth stepper.  
Major work in progress, tell me what is unclear and I will fix it.

• Install the attached firmware
  • connect up the uglier cable hack (shown in the picture)
    Stepper Driver --> Motherboard
    Step --> SCL
    DIR --> SDA
    EN --> A0 (the same pin as the enable on the 4th stepper)
  • Add the attached 3G_6D.xml file to your replicator G machines/ folder.
  • Start Replicator G with the printer disconnected and choose Machine -> Machine Type (Driver) then select: "3G 6D Cupcake (Gen3 XYZ, Mk5/6+Gen4 Extruder)" as your machine. (Make sure in ReplicatorG -> Preferences you have checked: "Show experimental machine profiles".)
  • Connect your bot and restart ReplicatorG
  • Open control panel and make sure the fifth motor works with motor B.

comments.text: I like the idea but would recommend that you share the step and direction signals and use seperate lines to enable each stepper. you would never run both extruders at the same time
comments.author: rbisping

comments.text: Thanks for your comment.  Actually if you watch your bot electronics during a build you will notice the enable lines are always active during a build (except the z axis).  The extruder steppers need to be enabled to produce holding torque.  If two stepper extruders shared step and direction signals as you suggest they would be extruding at the same time, which is not the idea.
comments.author: rbisping

comments.text: I think what he's saying is tying the stepper enable to separate pins, and sharing the direction and step signals.  For the extruder, you don't need holding torque when it's off (enable low).  So, you'd toggle enable between the two steppers, with only one on at a time.  This would still require four pins though so you wouldn't save a pin (unless you hacked in some step up/down resistors and modded one to be enabled when low, too much trouble).  It WOULD however result in less power draw, since you'd be energizing only X,Y, and one extruder, instead of both.  For people with finicky power supplies, this might be a good option.
comments.author: cpt_caveman

title: Tiny filament spool for small printers (M8 rod axis)

description.text:
I needed a small filament spool to put alongside with one of my little printers to keep things small and portable, so I made this thing. I kept the core at 50mm diameter to avoid filament break and also a 70mm length to store enough of it. It is still tiny enough and nice. The inner hole diameter is 9mm to be holded by a M8 rod. You will also need 6xM4 bolts & nuts to complete the setup. You'll also need 2x608zz bearings in case you use the bearing version. 608zz core version requires support for printing.

HINT: To attach the beginning of the filament to the core use a tiny bit of tape or use the filament insert hole.

UPDATE (11-MAY-2016): Added two new core models for lower core profiles of 50mm and 40mm height. This maintains the proportion similar as a normal spools, making the whole thing very cool, altough it stores less filament. I didn't made any measure but I think it could handle almost 80m of 1.75 filament. Cool for a miniprinter. The beer in the pic is just for scale comparison purposes, you know...

UPDATE (10-MAY-2016): Added two new models for two 608zz embedded bearings spool. In this case the core model requires touching buildplate support. This model runs smoother but this increases the risk of filament unspooling. Added a filament insert hole. Deleted simple side model to avoid confussion, the 608ZZ version works with both cores.

Another PiGRRL"0.2" was designed based on Pocket PiGRRL(and PiGRRL2 also).

Pocket PiGRRL
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:807591
PIGRRL 2
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1277483

Requirements are almost the same as PiGRRL.
The cost should be reduced by adoption of Raspberry Pi Zero and 2.2"LCD.
On the other hand, the complicatedness of soldering and assembling will
wipe out the advantage of the cost.

-Requirement.
Raspberry Pi Zero
micro SD card (for RetroPie).
adafruit 2.2inch LCD (or compatible device)
adafruit PowerBoost 1000C
LiPo battery 2000mAh
Slide Switch
Tactile Button switch (6mm) x 10pcs
Tactile Button switch (6mm slim) x 4pcs
socket header ( needed only 10pin )
Resistor : 270 ohm x 2pcs, 150 ohm x 2pcs
Capacitor : 33nF x 2pcs, 10uF x 2pcs
Diode (BAV99 compatible or similar) : 4pcs
Some wires & soldering tools
M2.6x8mm BOLT x 9pcs
Universal board for Raspberry Pi
2x20pin Female header or IDC-BreakoutHelper-2x20_40pin

The following items are required if you try to sound a speaker.
Audio amp.board, PAM8302
Mini metal speaker
The square fragment(21x24mm) of Breadboard PCB

The following items are required if you try to hear sound with earphone.
3.5mm mini stereo earphone jack
The square fragment(36x24mm) of Breadboard PCB

For more datails, Please refer to readme PDF file, "readme_anotherpigrrl0p2.pdf".

-update 6/13/2017
"pizero_225.123dx" has been fixed.
-Unnecessary hidden sketches have been deleted.

-The following problem was pointed out.
When "show sketch" is done, a lot of unnecessary sketches appear, and the operation of 123D becomes dull.
That problem will disappear.

title: Wooden Train Connections For Melissa & Doug Wooden Garage

description.text:
My nephew got the Melissa and Doug Wooden Service Garage: http://www.amazon.com/Melissa-Doug-Service-Station-Parking/dp/B012WE8YX6

He's really into Thomas trains now, so I thought I would 3D print some connector pieces that allow him to add this garage as part of the track.

Printing the two pieces allow you to connect standard Thomas/Brio/Imagniarium wooden track pieces to the elevator shaft and ramp on the garage.

One of my first original designs and prints... let me know what you guys think!

"Japanese Erasers" have been very popular with kids for several years, as have keychains that hang in bunches on the outside of backpacks. I find both, though the erasers in particular, to be excellent 3D learning tools. When taken apart they're reduced to basic 3D shapes that can be modeled on the computer then reconstructed as 3D printed objects, which are wonderful keepsakes of their class. I also consider joinery to be an important early skill for young inventors to develop. So the most interesting designs in my class are those that consist of multiple pieces that are interesting whether together or as a pile of printed parts. The creation of this simple object, together with others that I've uploaded to Thingiverse, are useful exercises for anybody learning 3D modeling.
Bob Krause
Inventor Studios
Berkeley, CA

The K-Extruder was designed to handle 3mm filament, but has often been re-purposed to handle 1.75mm. The problem I have found is that the filament tends to get off-track and slip off of the idler bearing.

To fix this, I have added two "guides" on either side of the filament to keep it lined up with the bearing.
A pre-defined support is included so printing as is will work.

Easy to print unversal mount for the GoPro.
Just put two zip ties through the holes and connect your GoPro to any rod or whatever you want to tie it to. The mount has two pairs of holes, so it can be used horizontally and vertically.
The only thing you need ist the screw and nut from another mount and the zip ties.
This version works with zip ties up to a width of 5 mm. With this size you don't need any support for the holes, but feel free to customize for your needs.

description.text:
Design Intent

20MM spacer designed for the ZMR 250 quadcopter. The intent is to use this spacer between the 2 bottom plates and place electronics between the plates and forgo all standard standoffs and the top plate to create a slimmer and lighter ZMR250.

This design does have the major drawback of encasing all electronic making modifying/replacing components a challenge.

Please let my know if you'd like the .IPT file to edit.

Features

  • XT60 holder in the back eliminate stress on the cables - no friction fit for XT60. I have been using super glue to hold the connector in place
  • Hole in back for SMA mount.
  • USB access on the side designed for USB mount in center of board like Naze32.
  • Hole for FPV camera up front - Recommended camera - no mount for camera currently included.
  • Designed for use with 3mm thick arms
  • 3 mounting holes for each arm to free up space on the inside.
  • Pass through on arms for ESC wiring.

Printer:

Monoprice Maker Select

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

  • My first prints have all been with just PLA and have been incredibly strong.

  • Strongest with 2-3 outer shells and 4 or more top and bottom layers.

  • The only supports I used were for the oval and circular shaped holes for the camera and SMA hole. Al other gaps are easily bridged.

Seeing the other tesla valve, I was pretty certain that the same principle could be extended to 3D. I came across a more symmetric, optimized design of a tesla microvalve at http://www.senlin41.org/topology-optimization-of-tesla-type-microvalve/ and traced it. The following is a trace of the optimized valve in openscad with added support to make it printable without overhang or flying parts. Parameters allow you to set the coarseness of the rotational extrusion ($fn=32 works fine for me), and the distance of the support bridges. I have not printed or tested that yet, so I suggest you start with the scad file and adapt it to your needs.

The scad is divided up into the modules tube: the outer tube. Just a cylinder with matching dimensions.
negative_space: everything you have to subtract from a tube to obtain a valve. (shown upside-down in the picture - in case you were wondering about printability)
positive_space: all the bridges and islands within the negative space.
valve: a complete valve = tube-negative space You may also want to add a second set of bridges on the other side of the "bullet" for stability, and to deal with vibrations.

description.header: This is an entry for the #backtoschool Challenge
description.text:
Objectives:
  • good functionality
  • no sharp edges
  • sufficient sturdiness
  • use of a moderate amount of material
  • acceptably nice look

Since compared to 2D printers 3D printers have limited resolution it is intened to print the scale on paper or transparent foil and glue it onto the rulers edge with scotch tape. I've included a ruler vectorgraphic file (easily editable with inkscape).  The rounded ends of the ruler are slightly elevated. They protude over the rulers thickness in the center area. Those protrusions are there to prevent the scotch tape from getting ripped off accidentally.

I suggest printing the pencil topper with three color-layers e.g. red black green so that the eyes and mouth stay black. Stick it onto your pencil and signal yes or no; good mood or bad mood when putting up your hand.

Print it like a vase. Set the Wallthickness to 1mm.
If you want a different wallthickness you must recompile the *.scad file with a different t paraneter. All files should be customizer ready, but they are in different *.scad files so I can't activate customizer here.

Do not use glow in the dark PLA for the ruler.
The phosphorizing strontium-aluminate-powder which is mixed im makes the surface very rough. So much that the lines get shaky.
this is a exercising thing but it may be light so make bigger on the MakerBot app to make it more heavier for you to exersise

title: Mauler 180 w/ 15° Motor Mounts - FPV Quadcopter

description.text:
I recently made my own quadcopter (found here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1521672) and started messing around with angled motor mounts and really liked how it's so easy to fly fast. While trying different angles I settled on 15° and I'm very happy with the performance. The main part of the frame and arms is 6mm thick with the front/rear inner sections being 1.5mm thick and the middle inner section being 2.5mm thick. It will accept any 220X size motors with a 16x19mm mounting pattern and is designed for 4 inch props. The motor mounting holes are recessed for m3x8 screws and there is 6mm of material between the motors and screw heads. The slots in the front of the frame are made for camera mounts similar to the ones that come with the HS1177 or Runcam Swift FPV cameras. The camera bracket is threaded with m3 holes to eliminate the need for front standoffs and works with the HS1177 or Runcam Swift cameras. The bracket is 30mm tall so you would need 6 - 30mm standoffs to complete the build.

The bottom frame weighs 72.3 grams printed with 70% infill.
The top plate weighs 13.2 grams printed with 50% infill.
The camera bracket weighs 4.8 grams printed with 30% infill.

The total weight of the frame, top plate and camera bracket is 90.3 grams.

The AUW (no battery) with the following parts is 295.1 grams.

RMRC Seriously Dodo Flight Controller
Armattan Simple PDB
Pololu 5v regulator
Little Bee 20a ESCs
RMRC 2204-2600kv motors
DAL 4045BN Props
LemonRx Spektrum Satellite Rx
Aomway 200mw VTx
HobbyKing E-OSD
Runcam Swift FPV camera

Suggested batteries would be 4s from 1000mAh to 1500mAh.

Updated - 6/29/16: Added an 1806 version with 15 degree motor tilt. Download the 15Degree_1306_Mauler.stl file. It is designed to work with the existing top plate and camera mount.

Like my stuff? Buy me a beer. Donations are accepted and greatly appreciated.

A rather simple Container that is designed to look nice. With about 10CM height, it's a bit short for a vase, but if you have some short flowers, it should look nice.

Not much needed

Notes:

The default size took my printer about 6 hours - at 0.3 layer height (with a 0.4 nozzle) and 50mm/s print speed.

Obviously, it'd look better with 0.2 or even 0.1 .

If you have it, I recommend printing with LayBrick or similar - the layers are far less visible then and it looks much better.

Put together in Tinkercad, ran through Meshmixer/Netfabb to fix it.

The statues come from Bioshock (see separate section), while the rest is entirely Tinkercad.

So it actually isn't really much design that went into it, more a trial and error to see if everything fits together :-)

In case you're curious, the "ring" in the lower half isn't just decoration - the female statues in the original setting are suspended using a rig that covers their lower half - you can see the rest of it still - it's mostly visible at the midsection, the ring is supposed to cover that, while at the same time making sure all the statues have at least one point where they're firmly affixed to the whole design.

Bioshock

The statues on the outside were taken from one of the Bioshock games (might be one of the Rapture DLCs of Infinite).

I've always liked the decor statues of Bioshock (or the previous Batman movies) so I was delighted to see it's possible to extract them from the game.

I'm hesitant to publish this, as I'm not sure if this is covered by fair use or not. So in any case, I ask that no one tries to make money off the design, or its components.

The statues have been modified somewhat, since the game only stores rough geometric forms, any smoothness actually came from the texture. My attempts have not been as successfully as I hoped, but I think it's acceptable.

If you have (bought) a copy of Bioshock (or 2, or inifinte) you should be able to extract the models yourself - download UEViewer, or any other program that can extract resources from the Unreal Engine.
You'll need to convert the PSK(X) files, so you will have to download Blender as well (I think the required plugin should be included, if not search for Blender PSKX plugin).
Import in Blender, Export as STL.
If you find a way to smooth the corners on the way, please tell me :-)

3D printed designs are often NOT waterproof, and certainly not food safe!

Putting water (or any liquid) into a printed container probaby isn't a good idea. Even if you're just putting in flowers, it might not do them any good (best case, it just evaporates through tiny holes).

To get around this, you can put a bag into the vase:

Wrap the open end of the bag around the inner ring, put the bag inside the container and close it up with the outer ring.
Done right the outer ring will conceal the bag from the outside, unless you're looking directly from above you don't even know it's in there.

(Of course, a better alternative might be to coat the printed result with something that seals the tiny holes and creates a smooth surface. There are food grade resins and finishes, but I haven't really found anything that looks promising. Though I only spent about half an afternoon on Google :-)

title: Security cap for charger model IP30 (SPARTA, BATAVUS, KOGA, HERCULES and TUNTURI electric bike).

description.text:
The charger of an electric bike has a high voltage and high current.
34V DC - 3,4A The cable has no sensor switch or safety pin that closes the 34V circuit only when a bike is connected. Could be done with an nice delay by means of a MOSFET. So that burn of the pins is also prevented.

HINT: this might be a GOOD idea overpaid R&D design departments around the world !!!!

The bike isn't mine, so I just made a safety cap to prevent another short circuit, as it did last time the cable made contact with a conduction material.

I needed a quick-printed screwdriver, here it is. I had to push to get the pin to place. Adjust your printer settings to get it right according to it precision. It is made for hexagonal screwdrivers' head.

I like the USP 45 Site Mount but I needed something that fit my .40 Beretta PX4 Storm. So, I rebuilt it from the ground up in Tinkercad to let me make alterations where needed to fit my handgun. I added 3 rails and an extension with a bottom rail on the front end as part of the print. I cut the hex holes for the screws to fit a 6/32 machine screw I picked up from the local hardware store. If you want a different screw size, feel free to message me.

If you're wondering if this will fit your pistol, the first file is "tri rail test slice". It's a half inch slice of my frame. If it slides over your sights and fits snugly on your rails then it should fit your gun. If not, please let me know and I can make some adjustments. It fits my .40 baretta PX4 but had some issue with a glock .40 so I'm tinkering a little with the dimensions.

DISCLAIMER Putting a vertical grip on a pistol is illegal without the AOW Stamp or SBR Stamp. If you want to use a foregrip on a handgun it must be angled. However, feel free to throw whatever you like on an airsoft gun or any non-lethal weapons you use these prints on :)

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/ia8SydHX2tq

remixed_from.author: blah_59
remixed_from.title: Azteeg X3 Improved Clip for Cerberus (or any 8020.net 1515 series printer)

description.text:
A low profile clip that snaps onto an ATMega2560 controller board and snaps into 8020 rail. No hardware necessary! Holds the board tight and holds the rail tight. What more can I say? What more do you need?
Want even stronger grip on the rail and PCB? Just edit the design file to make the clip wider.
It's easy to edit the .skp or .stl files to fit other PCBs- just make the space between the "balls" on the PCB side of the clip about 1mm smaller than your PCB width and you'll get a satisfying "click" when the clip snaps on the board (it sort of reminds me of the snap you feel when the two halves of a cashew separate in your mouth! mmmmm!).

Print two (or more) at a time and use them to hold your printer's controller board to the 8020 rail.  I printed using Ocatve Green 1.75mm ABS filament with neither raft nor brim, 0.25mm first layer, 0.2mm for other layers, avoid crossing perimeters, 0.2mm retraction on layer change, print at 235C.  Comes off the printer ready to use, no clean-up necessary!

author: jamesgrimm0130

description.text: The goal is to make 3mm filament from PET drinking Bottles. NOTE: This needs serious redesign! (To this melting chamber any kind of drive can be mounted and any kind of plastic can bee fed but a PET-band stepper-feed is planned edit: is considered) The he Centi PET Re-Extruder shall be easier to build and cheaper than exiting re-extruder projects. This shall be reached by making it smaller (20cm desktop size instead of 1m workbench size) and requiring its maximum output speed not to be very high (>= one printer input speed). For a fully functional system additionally to this melting chamber there will be needed: PET Cutter (A); PET Band Feeder & Guider (B); Filament cooler & catcher (C) Those are not yet constructed. This Melting chamber is Heavily influenced by the existing projects: http://reprap.org/wiki/Web4Deb_extruder http://www.appropedia.org/Waste_plastic_extruder http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:12948 http://recyclebot.tumblr.com/ http://www.kickstarter.com/projects/rocknail/filabot-plastic-filament-maker The only differences are that it is smaller (thumb sized melting chamber) and it has some additional features which are only possible since it's a 3d printed design. Those features will be more thorougly discussed in the following design decisions section: DESIGN DECISIONS: Since its smaller size it has much more surface area per volume and thus huge-er thermal losses. So a bit more care must be taken for thermal isolation. SEE: [INSTRUCTIONS -> Assembly] for application of thermal isolation. The chamber is open on both ends => easy cleaning easy nozzlechange and nice thermal isolation with fibreglas-PCB endplates. The chamber is symmetrical => no wrong assembly possible. Lots of spikes (16) and wedgecuts (2) provide air pockets under the isolation to give additional thermal isolation. The screw aligners are open and sharp pointed for minimized thermal contact to the screws. Wall thicknesses are kept minimal for lower material volume and thus price. Lamellas: PET has a very high thermal resistance [0.28W / (m*K)]. The steel lamellas [shapeways infused steel: 22.6 W/(m*K)] decrease the termal equilibration time quite a lot. The gap between lamellas should be choosen as a tradeof. With smaller gap size the maximum feed speed for reasonable thermal exchange rises but if the gaps become too narrow viscous friction will kick in (laminar flow). An optimal geometry would require numerical simulations and narrowing gaps (this is overkill). The minimum lamella thickness is given by the printing process and should be around 1.5mm for steel prints. The outer isolation (thermal resistance similar to PET) should be thicker than the distance between lamellas. I hope the airpockets are ganna help here. As of now I've choosen the gap size as small as possible so that it remains reasonably cleanable but it wouldn't hurt to do some conservative estimative calculations. (TODO)

I chose PET as primary feeding material out of following reasons: 1) Drinking Bottle PET has a reasonable low melting point ( 230Â°C ) (due to some additives ?) SEE: http://blog.reprap.org/2009/03/drink-bottle-feedstock.html I tested melting it with my soldering iron set to 220Â°C and it melted easily! 2) It can be cut to very slim long stripes which lend themselve for feeding into a small melting chamber entrance with an hobbed bolt drive (no auger drill drive intended) For cutting devices I found this nice website: http://www.utsumi.com.br/pet/English/filetador/index.html

description.header: The first two steps in PET bottle processing must be treated with different parts that are yet to be constructed
description.text:
Centi PET Cutter -- see (A) below

Centi PET Band Feeder & Guider -- see (B) below

3) Very good mechanical properties prints similar to PLA (diff temp) but is not brittle at all. Though hygroscopicness & re-crystallisation may degrade it a bit. 4) IMO it smells less obnoxious than HDPE fumes ################################### TODO (A) Petcutter Is it possible to construct a small one that is easy to handle? (B) Feeder & Guider the drive mechanism must solve

  • backlog

  • PET band creasing avoidance or control over it ("snakelooping")

    "channel to be the thickness of the folded strip"

    => maybe too thinn to print.

    directly feeding the pet band to a printer?

    => probably not for an bowden tube printer.

    • (C) Filament Cooler & Catcher important for constant diameter design so that it can be directly fed into a bowden tube ####################################

It doesn't work in its current state and needs redesign! The heat transport is by far not good enough. Some ideas for improvement: *) no thermal isolation spikes for airgaps - use glasswool instead *) include a printed tangential coil groove for Isolated NiCr Wire? (if done silver is needed as material for high enough surface resolution) *) conic tip to avoid non-flowing volumes *) use an PTFE block for the camber entrance as thermal isolation & mounting structute *) compressing PET-bottles to sticks with quadratic cross section at T>Tg but T<Tmelt so it doesnt become sticky (think flatironing) => square pipe and heating chamber? *) some piston feeding mechanism ... random crude idea: crunched bottle stick comes in (low force) a very high force adjustable wrench like mechanism repeatedly cuts off and pushes a the tip of a warmcrunched pet bottle rod 90 degree to feedpipe into the melting chamber. (safety like this: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=esnQwVZOrUU)

This print was from Shapeways: http://www.shapeways.com/model/edit/428909/ Shapeways stainless steel [22.6 W/(m*K)] (it's bronce infused) All wall thicknesses are chosen for this material. (1.5mm is ok, I've tested this ***) http://www.shapeways.com/materials/stainless_steel Silver with a whopping [429 W/(m*K)] is even better but probably too expensive for most people. Preaparations: *) Order Heating barrel *) Cut fibreglass-PCB-isolation-plates or silicone or cork (remains to be tested) pate geometries are in the *.scad file (note to myself: make dxf files) Assembly: 1) Wrap the main barrel in approx 1mm teflon (or kapton) so that every screw can still touch the barrel on both ends simultaneously. Don't tension too much - leave the intended air pockets. 2) Put the heater cartridge & thermocouple on the heater peg and wrap it with teflon (or kapton) to fix them in place (alternatively connect a temperature regulated soldering iron lateron). 3) On four M3 screws put in order: two or more fibreglass-PCB isolation plug plates; nozzle plate (aluminium ? or fiberglass as nozzle plate ? ...); THIS THING the metal heating barrel (symmetrical => both ways correct); two or better more fibreglass-PCB completely open with the big hole in the middle; your custom extrusion mechanism output flange (avoid PLA). Screw evrything together with four/eight nuts. 4) Wrap a final layer of teflon (or kapton) above the screws => additional air pockets. 5) TRY IT (chamber must be horizontal and the cartridge peg must look down) 6) POST IT :) I wanted to desing it for for those two but couldnt find exact measures: https://shop.ultimaker.com/en/cartridge-heater-40w-at-18v.html https://shop.ultimaker.com/en/tc-sensor.html Currend barrel cuts are 5mm and 3mm diameter and 25mm length. ESTIMATIONS!!

title: Fan duct for LOGresse (Prusa Steel) carriage and radial fan

description.text:
This new fan duct for a radial fan and single extruder aims to blow efficiently around the deposited material, while keeping view and acces to the front part of the nozzle.
The efficiency is partly due to several thin walls that guide and distribute the air flow along the fan duct. You can see their shapes on the last picture (cut view from CAD model)
It has been designed to be mounted on the x-carriage of the LOGresse (https://www.logre.eu/wiki/Logresse/en)
There have been several versions. On version 4b the fan is fixed by two screws M3.
Version 5b seems to be simpler and more efficient than previous ones, with only one screw (probably enough while the output side of the fan is inserted in the fan duct).

You can also try to open the crenels, or not. (it has been done on the picture for the green version).

The "wedge" (not sure it is the good translation in English) may be put between the carriage and the fan duct support, in order to obtain a different lateral position of the fan duct. Useful if the hot end is mounted in a non symetrical way. As the model is 1mm thick, you should just print it horizontally with a vertical scale factor corresponding to the gap you want to keep in the assembly.

Finally, if you need (or want) to mount your fan on the left side of the carriage, print the parts after mirroring! The fan will still fit perfectly.

title: Parametric Boltless Hook for keyhole shelving units

description.text: Turn the unused keyholes in boltless shelves into practical hanging space. Using 2 keyholes in the uprights this thing sits and provides a hook for things like scissors, headphones (I use 2 half shelves and a laminated MDF as a PC desk, huge desktop), pots and pans and a whole thingiverse of items. Make your own custom 3d prints that are held up with this print. Yes itâ€™s completely parametric so it will work with any brand of keyhole style boltless shelves The bridge in the model might sag, as long as it minimal it should add to prints snug fitting. (Yes it works better without a perfect bridge) Some of the pics are of the non parametric version; it has a smaller wedge in the hook but otherwise is near identical to the openSCADâ€™s uploaded stl BTW: http://www.makerbot.com/blog/2012/01/30/openscad-what-would-you-like-to-learn-next/ update(9th Jan 2013)made changes to work with Customizer

Measure your shelves boltless keyhole
Plug the 4 main measurements into openSCAD (key: small, big, spacing and thickness)
Add tolerances to your measurements for clearances.
Change the hook parameters if you need to (it will allow you do add impractical values so review the model) Render save and print .... Profit

comments.text: Haven't been watching the chute on Thingiverse for long enough to have spotted this when it was posted, but I've been thinking I need the exact same thing for hanging up commonly used tools and safety gear on my shelving. Really need to get myself a printer and print up a dozen or two of these. Great idea!

Hi,

I will post here all my modifications made to my Tronxy P802 MA (P802MA). You will probably need a Dremel Tool to enlarge a little holes for bearings & stems !

1 - bottom_z_axis_bearing_block_rescaled_P802MA.stl :
This is a bottom bearing block, originally made by @rizer and modified by me, for the P802MA printer. This part must be printed twice (one for the left Z motor side and one for the right Z motor side).

Bearing used must be 22mm outer diameter (i used 608ZZ bearing).

2 - top_z_axis_bearing_block_left_P802MA.stl :
This is the top bearing block made by me (design in progress) for the left side. Use symmetry to print the right side. The bearings used are the same as the bottom part (608ZZ).

description.text: maqueta

This is a small box for placing the Arduino Nano and DS1302 inside. Used for my LED clock project.

The lid is press fit, so you should have a very well calibrated printer, or you have to resize the lid.
Every object is colored differently because the main similarity in all of the objects is that they all have incandescence making the colors look  cooler, and it is fun to make.

Pencil Case
  • Extruded a sphere into the shape that the case is in.
  • Lowered a piece of the case then extruded and deleted the sides of the extruded object after raising the piece.
  • Assigned new material and colored the object using red and adding incandescence.
  • Added details and other such things to the case.
    • Ruler
  • Created a plane
  • Extruded upward.
  • Placed rises in the ruler, each an inch apart.
  • Assigned a material to the ruler.
  • Assigned a material to the areas that rose out of the ruler.
    • Pencil topper/eraser
  • Created a sphere
  • Extruded bands and formed them into the shape wanted.
  • Deleted the area that the eraser would go into.
  • Extruded edges around area and closed off the center.
  • Assigned material and colored object.

print_settings.Notes:: 2 outer shells and 3-4 top and bottom layers

description.text:
Design Intent

NOTE: Does not bolt to traditional top plate of ZMR 250. It is also Important that the battery strap is secured through the top plate of the quadcopter and not just threaded through the gap on the side of the battery holder. This is not strong enough on it's own to hold the battery down.

A battery holder designed to mount on a ZMR 250 quadcopter bottom plate. The mounting pattern will not fit on the top of the top plate of the ZMR 250. Intended to be used with one of the thin profile spacers such as mine HERE which do not make use of the top plate.

specifically for Turnigy Multistar Elite 1400 3s and 4s batteries.

Features

  • Designed around Turnigy Multistar Elite 3S and 4s batteries
  • Securely holds a battery from sliding around in all direction with only 1 battery strap.
  • Pass one battery strap through top plate slots on ZMR 250 from then up and around battery.
  • Capture nuts for 3mm nuts to install easily with only one hex driver.

comments.text: Because he just took my object and Boolean intersected it to get rid of the watermark. That's no redesign or mix. That's like taking a coke, putting a sandwich aside and then renaming the coke pepsi, because you changed it.

comments.text:
Fair enough. If that's the case then he should probably not have uploaded it, or at least given credit and a link.
Honestly though, I prefer not having any logos, watermarks, names, or anything identifying on my stuff and usually try to delete those, so I can understand why he would do that. But your right, uploading it in that condition without credit is kinda shady.
